title: Is it possible to be the victim of a conspiracy theory?
self_text: I was reading about the QAnon movement, and was thinking about how people can genuinely believe something like that is real, even though there’s no evidence.  I know that many conspiracies are just made up for entertainment, but what if someone actually believes in a conspiracy because they see some “evidence” or have a specific reason to believe it?  For example, let’s say I found some odd connections between events in my town, so I thought I would do research on the topic, and then found some information online supporting an idea that is completely ridiculous. Does that mean I’m a part of a conspiracy, or am I just misinterpreting data?  Do I become a target of the conspiracy after that?   I feel like people are trying to convince me that the only way to not be part of a conspiracy is to ignore any other evidence, and just accept whatever narrative is presented.  What are your thoughts?

title: How much do you think a real person could handle?
self_text: Is there a limit to how much abuse someone can endure before they snap?   I mean, are we just going to assume that everyone can handle whatever the world throws at them? Is it not possible for some people to be able to withstand a level of torture or trauma that would crush most others? I'm just wondering if anyone has ever come across people who seem like they have almost no limits to what they can endure?

title: How does the internet work?
self_text: I was just wondering how the internet works, and I can't find a good answer anywhere.

title: How to write a good story?
self_text: Ok so I wanna be a writer but I dont know how to start or what makes a good story. If you could give me any advice on writing stories, please do.

title: What's the difference between "you are a liar" and "you lie"?
self_text: Is there any difference in meaning? I thought that if you were lying, it would be more appropriate to say “you are a liar” but then I saw someone use “you lie” as a way of telling you that what you said was not true.

title: How does a person with extreme anxiety and depression cope with having to go out in public?
self_text: My friend has been suffering from severe anxiety and depression for the past 5 years, she is currently unable to get out of bed some days. I am trying to help her but it's hard because when she gets an idea about going out, she starts to panic.  I would like to know how she can cope with these thoughts or feelings. It feels as though she has no agency over her life. She doesn’t want to go out, yet she also knows that if she doesn’t go out, she will be miserable. Any advice you have would be appreciated.

title: Why do some people find it weird to make a cup of tea and then drink it without making another cup?
self_text: I find it very weird to drink hot tea, but then not make another cup for myself. Like why don't you just make more? It doesn't seem like much effort to me.  I think there are many reasons why this might be the case, which is why I'm curious about what you guys think about this.

title: Is it possible to live on a diet of only noodles and broth?
self_text: This is a stupid question, I know, but I just had an epiphany and have been thinking about how much carbs you can get out of noodles and broth.  I was reading something that said that the average person in America eats around 200g of pasta per week.  I'm pretty sure my weekly noodle consumption would be at least as high, if not higher.   So like, could someone survive eating nothing but noodles and broth (for a few weeks/months)?  I'm just curious what would happen to your body after a while...

title: Does someone get a second chance to make it up when they fail an exam?
self_text: So if you have a horrible test grade and are upset with yourself for the rest of your life, would that be possible to change that feeling?

title: What is the difference between a "muffler" and a "silencer"?
self_text: I've been hearing these two words used interchangeably but I know they are different, just don't know what the difference is.

title: What's the point of doing a job that you hate?
self_text: I think about my current job and I think it’s such a waste of time. It doesn’t pay well, I can't use my skills, and it makes me depressed. So why do people keep doing jobs they hate?

title: How do you get your child to stop yelling and be quiet? (Is it normal for them to do so?)
self_text: My son is a little over a year old, he just keeps yelling and screaming at the top of his lungs all day long. I can't hear anything else but him screaming, and it's driving me crazy. He does this when he wants something or doesn't like what's happening. Does that sound normal?  What should I do?

title: What is the purpose of a car wash?
self_text: You drive through and it comes out clean. Why do people pay for this? Do they not have access to water or soap at home?

title: What is the name of that show?
self_text: I watched a show last night and it was really interesting but the name of it keeps slipping my mind so help me out if you can!

title: How do you get a good deal when buying something?
self_text: I've been seeing online ads saying "Buy One Get One Free" or "20% off".  I have no idea how to tell if that is really worth it, because some things are overpriced anyway.  How does someone determine whether or not they should buy something on sale?

title: How to handle a friend who is always at the bar and never ever does anything else?
self_text: I know how that sounds, but my friend has no other hobbies or interests.  They're only about 23 years old, so they can still do other things with their lives.  They just want to drink all day long, every single day. And it’s getting annoying.  I’m trying to be supportive of them because they have mental health issues (they said so) but I don’t want to enable them. Is there any way to help them change their lifestyle without causing conflict?

title: How do I know if a person is a good person?
self_text: I want to be able to tell how someone feels about me and how they are towards other people in general. Like, should I just trust that if someone has done something bad in the past, they have changed?   Is it possible for humans to change?

title: Does a company have to follow laws even if they do not want to?
self_text: If the government says that something is illegal, can you just ignore it? Can you avoid following a law and still keep doing business? I heard there were many companies that ignored COVID regulations, but they got shut down anyway.

title: How can you get a good hair cut without going to the salon?
self_text: I don't have time to go to the salon and I am getting tired of cutting my own hair. It is so frustrating when it doesn't look how I want it to, and I can never figure out how to properly trim it myself.  I have been using an electric clipper for years, but my haircuts always come out uneven or patchy. Is there any way that I could get a good haircut by myself?

title: Is there a way to make it so that people do not get mad at you when they say that they don't like a certain kind of food?
self_text: I find myself getting annoyed when people say things like "I hate broccoli" or "I can't stand spaghetti". This is because I think that everyone should be able to enjoy any kind of food and therefore shouldn't be made to feel bad for liking it.  Is there anything that can be done about this?

title: Why do we call them "slushies" when they are ice and water?
self_text: It's literally just ice and water, what else could you call it?? Like a smoothie or milkshake?  I'm not even sure why there is a word for it...

title: What does it mean when someone says they are in a mood to "get sick" and get out of their responsibilities?
self_text: I was reading some online forums about people who claim that being sick is the only way they can avoid responsibility, and they would rather stay home and be miserable than do anything. Like how they don't have any sympathy for others who are sick, because they think that getting sick is an excuse to not do anything. It really bothered me and I wanted to know what the psychological reasons could be behind such behavior.

title: Is it weird to not want to be on a diet?
self_text: I hate dieting, and I have no desire to change my weight. If I get fat, so be it.  I'm a large guy, but I don't see the point in being skinny.

title: Why do some people say "I'm not sure" when asked a question that can be answered with a simple yes or no?
self_text: I get the idea that someone doesn't want to give an opinion, but isn't it just wasting everyone's time for them to ask a simple question and then answer "yes" or "no"?

title: What is the purpose of a 'public' toilet?
self_text: I always find it weird that public toilets are called "public" but they aren't actually open to the public, because they can only be accessed by those with a key or card.   If they are meant for the public, why do they need a key/card?  Are there other considerations that I am not aware of?

title: How do I use a microwave when there are no instructions?
self_text: Is it even possible to figure out how to use an appliance without instructions?  If so, what is the method for figuring out how to use something like that?

title: What’s the deal with the “this is fine” meme?
self_text: I've seen it a lot recently on Reddit, and I’m confused as to why.

title: Is it possible for a person to be "unhappy" when they are happy?
self_text: I was thinking about something and had some questions that were difficult to answer. When someone is truly happy, how can they feel unhappy or depressed at the same time? Like if you have everything you could ever want, why would you be sad? Is this just an illusion?

title: How do you know if your partner is cheating on you?
self_text: I'm not trying to be paranoid, but my ex boyfriend was an abusive person and he used to lie about his whereabouts a lot. He would always tell me that he was at work when I saw him with other people or doing things that he wasn't supposed to do. Now he's dating someone else and I don't know how to deal with it.  I feel like I'm going crazy because all of the red flags are there and I can't seem to shake them off. Is it normal for someone to just ignore their own gut feelings?

title: Why does it feel like most of the people on here are miserable?
self_text: I've been feeling kind of down lately and I'm just wondering if I'm alone in feeling that way or not.   I don't know why, but a lot of the posts here seem to be about people complaining, being sad, feeling lonely, etc..  Is it just me?  Or is there something wrong with everyone?

title: Why do people say that the government is a lie?
self_text: I've seen it a lot in comments and tweets, so what are they saying?

title: How do you know when your child is in a coma?
self_text: My mother said my father was in a coma for 2 weeks after he had a stroke and the doctors told her that she should be able to see if he was conscious or not (by looking at his face, eyes etc.) because they can't fully diagnose him until they run more tests. So I wondered how doctors are sure it isn't just an unconscious state of shock and fear?

title: I have been watching videos of how to make a vegan ramen and it looks so good but you can't eat the broth in any of them, why?
self_text: Can anyone explain why no one makes or posts videos about making vegan ramen that involves drinking the broth, is there something that stops people from doing this?

title: I'm a very large person, but do I need to eat more calories than other people?
self_text: A lot of the advice I see online is for average sized people, and not much for larger people. Like if I am eating less calories than others, will I be able to bulk up?  Also, how do you know if you are eating enough calories?

title: If you're being abused by your parents, should you leave home?
self_text: If you're being abused by your parents, and the abuse is severe enough that they refuse to get help (therapy or counseling) but aren't violent/harmful in a physical way, what do you do?  I have friends who are in similar situations, and it's hard for them to know what to do because their parents are so involved in their lives.

title: How many times do you have to fall down before you are considered a "faller"?
self_text: I was just watching an interview with a doctor who said that he has been seeing more and more kids fall in school, but they don't call them fallers anymore.  They say they are now called "falling" so as not to stigmatize the children.   So how many times does it take for someone to be considered a "faller"?

title: What is a good way to get my cat to stop scratching at the curtains?
self_text: My cats are very cute and playful, but they always scratch at the curtains when I'm not home. Do you have any advice for me?

title: Can you get a fake degree for the school you went to?
self_text: I am trying to apply to college but I don't want to be rejected because my transcript is not good enough.

title: Is there a reason why some of the most popular/successful people in entertainment and sports are often so incredibly talented at being friends with others?
self_text: I’ve noticed that some of the biggest names seem to have an easy time making friends, who also happen to be successful at their own careers. How do they do it? And does anyone know how to make good friends as well?

title: What is the deal with a dog being fed meat products and then they die of liver failure?
self_text: I was reading an article about how dogs get liver failure if they eat too much meat and it got me thinking. Like, why does this happen to them so often? Do dogs have more sensitive livers than humans do? Or are there some other biological reasons that make them more vulnerable? I’ve read a bunch of sources but nothing really answered my question.

title: How do you not get an ear infection?
self_text: I've had bad ear infections in the past and they always come back after antibiotics.  I'm trying to be more careful but it's hard, especially when I'm swimming or out in windy conditions. Is there anything else I can do besides antibiotics (like using a nose clip)?

title: Why do some people take their shoes off?
self_text: I was at a friend’s house yesterday and her mom told me she doesn’t want me to wear my shoes because the floors are cold and that she doesn’t like people wearing shoes in her house. She said it wasn't because of hygiene or anything. She also mentioned something about the floor being “soft” so I assumed it was carpet, but then I went to another friend’s house and they had hardwood floors with rugs. Why is it normal for some people to not wear shoes inside? Do they have sensitive feet? Is there an unspoken rule?

title: Is it possible to make a car engine out of a potato?
self_text: I'm thinking about building an engine and I was wondering if the potato could be used in some way?

title: What does “doing it for the kids” mean?
self_text: I’ve seen a lot of people use that phrase lately in an attempt to justify bad decisions, and frankly, I don’t get it. So what is the point?   I feel like people have been using it since the beginning of time, but I can't really figure out what it means beyond the obvious “for the kids” part.  What is actually meant by saying you are doing something for your kids?  Is it about ensuring their future success? Is it about showing them love? Or just trying to sound good?

title: What's the difference between a "revolving door" and a "rotational position"?
self_text: I'm trying to figure out what a revolving door is, and how it differs from a rotational position, which seems to be similar but with a different focus?

title: Why are there so many “How to be a good boyfriend” videos?
self_text: I'm pretty sure that the amount of resources available on YouTube about how to be a good boyfriend is excessive and it’s giving me a headache.

title: Why do they always take a photo of the first person who got shot or killed in any incident?
self_text: I keep seeing pictures of the first victim, and it seems odd to me that there is an immediate need to show the public that someone died.  Why do we need that first image? It’s just so traumatic.   Is it meant to make people feel like it could happen to them, or is it just morbid curiosity?

title: How does a person become a doctor?
self_text: In the US, how long does it take to become a licensed medical doctor and is there anything else that a candidate can do to improve their chances of being accepted into a school for doctors?

title: Is there a way to change the number of times the question is asked?
self_text: There are so many questions on Reddit that I have seen repeated multiple times, and each time they ask me if I am sure about my answer. The last question was asked 5 times in a row, and each time I answered the same way.  I don't think it will ever end. Does anyone know how to change the number of times you see the question?

title: Is there a way to change my name?
self_text: I'm trying to get rid of a bad nickname that people give me when they call me for a game night. I don’t like it and would love to be called by something else, but the problem is I have no idea how to change my name. How can you do that? And what if I want to use the same name in other apps, games or services?

title: Can you be a citizen of two countries?
self_text: I just moved to the US after living in Europe for 20 years, and now i want to become a citizen of both the US and the country that i used to live in. Is there any way to do that?

title: How do I make a good cake?
self_text: I'm trying to make a cake but every time it comes out burnt on the outside and raw in the middle. What can I do to stop that? Any tips or tricks?

title: Why is it that when a person with the same height as you are shorter than you, they appear to be taller?
self_text: I'm not asking about visual perception or how people can trick their eyes into seeing things differently. What am I missing here?

title: Why do we not use the word "bland" to describe food?
self_text: I'm asking because when you eat a bland meal, you would think of it as unappetizing, or that there is nothing of value in the food. You may feel like you need to add some spices, vegetables, etc., to make the dish more flavorful.  If you were to say the food was bland, then your friend may ask why and what is so wrong with the food.  I've noticed that most people don't even attempt to describe a bland food but just call it bland. What is it about the word bland that makes it an insufficient descriptor for food?

title: I’ve been trying to remember a really good song for the past two weeks, but my brain keeps erasing it every time I try to think about it.
self_text: It was on a song called “Hallelujah” by Leonard Cohen, and it goes like this:

title: What does it mean to be a "woke" person?
self_text: I've heard the term "woke" used as an insult and as a positive descriptor, so I don't know what that means. I don't want to get into a heated argument about politics, but if you could give me a definition of "woke", I would appreciate it.

title: Why do some people use "per" or "for" in the same sentence?
self_text: I was reading an article about a new phone and it used both words. It said, "It's for me to use." Then later it said, "I will be using per month". Is that weird? Or am I just being odd?  I don't understand why they would use two different words with similar meanings.

title: What is the difference between a sandwich and a wrap?
self_text: Is it just the bread, or is there something more to it than that?

title: If I go to the grocery store and find a box of cookies, but there is also a coupon for that cookie box on my phone, do I need to show the cashier or does it automatically apply?
self_text: I'm not sure if the coupon will be applied automatically when I scan the barcode at checkout or if I have to show them the coupon on my phone first.

title: Why do some people say that their parents' marriage was toxic?
self_text: My parents are married for over 30 years and have been together since high school. They're not always happy, but they don't fight, never argue or anything like that. I think they've just grown comfortable with each other and are okay with the state of their marriage. Is it possible to be in a relationship where both partners are at peace with how things are?

title: How do people manage to live in the middle east?
self_text: I have been reading about the Middle East for years and it seems like so many things are wrong with the place, but yet they still survive. Are there really no improvements coming? If not why? Is there a lack of political will or corruption?  I can’t even understand how people can still stay there without wanting to leave. I feel like everyone would want to move somewhere else if they had the chance.

title: How is it that a normal person can be a good cook but not a great cook?
self_text: I've had people who make a simple sandwich or pasta dish that tastes amazing, but then when they try to do something more complicated like roast chicken, the taste is completely off.

title: What are the reasons for using a VPN on a mobile phone?
self_text: I've been hearing about people using VPNs on their phones to avoid tracking and ads but I can't figure out what they actually do, so that's why I wanted to ask you all.  Also, it seems like many of these apps are scams or malware.  I want to know how they work and whether they would be useful for me.

title: Why do people put the food in a box and not directly into a container?
self_text: Like, if you are having lunch at work, why don't you just put it directly into your container instead of putting it inside a box first? Do people think that is more hygienic? Or do they want to be extra careful?

title: Why do people put a lot of effort into making the most aesthetically pleasing or beautiful things?
self_text: I've noticed that the more effort someone puts into something, the better it looks (i.e. the more beautiful it is). But why? Is there some evolutionary reason for it? Like if we were trying to attract mates with our appearance and stuff, how would we have been able to make things so perfect that it just seems like someone's going overboard?  I'm not saying beauty is bad, but when you see such an elaborate effort made just to create something that can be seen by other humans, it feels strange to me.  For example, people spend hours on social media creating really elaborate pictures/videos, etc. That's all just for likes right? Or does it serve some deeper purpose than just getting attention?

title: How is it possible to be a good person?
self_text: I am asking because I know that people can do bad things for many reasons (e.g. depression, being raised in an abusive family) and the idea of some people doing evil deeds for no reason seems so bizarre.  I'm not trying to find out how you can be "good", but rather the idea of humans just being generally good - is it even possible?  Are we all fundamentally wired with the ability to be good or are we always going to be prone to committing atrocities?

title: How do you know when you've found a good deal?
self_text: Like I was looking at a sale for a new phone and there was a discount of $200 on it but it still cost me $850 to buy. That doesn't seem like a good deal. Is there any way to tell if a deal is actually a good deal or not?  I don't want to be tricked by some company that sells the same product as everyone else but charges more because they have "sales"

title: What is the best way to remove a stain on a white shirt?
self_text: I had an ice cream cone and now there's a brown stain on my white shirt. Should I try rubbing alcohol, bleach or something else?

title: How many people have you ever worked with that were able to make a meal from scratch?
self_text: I was talking about my dad's job, and he said he used to work at a factory in the 80's where they had a kitchen for employees. He said some of his coworkers would bring ingredients and cook meals during lunch.  I was wondering how common it is for jobs to have kitchens or facilities to prepare food.  Not just break rooms with microwave ovens.

title: Is it weird to think about the person who made a video game being more alive than me?
self_text: This is just a thought that popped into my head, but it's so bizarre and unsettling that I wanted to share it.  Like, these characters in games have personalities, lives, and experiences, even though they aren't real. They exist only in someone else's imagination, yet they feel like they are more present than me. Like if i was watching an animated movie, I could be transported into that world and would probably experience the same things as those characters did in their lives. It's kinda scary thinking about how much more "alive" someone can be through a screen, even if you can physically see them.

title: Is there a reason why the world is so full of people who are constantly trying to be the first to do something?
self_text: I know that everyone has different goals and ambitions, but some people seem obsessed with being "first".

title: Is there a way to make the screen brighter on my phone?
self_text: My screen is super dim and I can barely see anything on it, so I'm wondering if there's any way to increase its brightness without me having to buy a new phone or something.

title: I can’t believe how many people have been shot in the US this year so far
self_text: In the last 7 months of 2023, there have been at least 600+ shootings.

title: What is a “protest” or “protest” and why can’t I be in it?
self_text: My mom says that I have to stay inside because I am not an adult but she also said if I go outside, I need to follow the rules of protest. Is there anything about being a child that prevents me from protesting, and how would I do so without breaking any laws?

title: If you can’t find any good deals, do you think it’s okay to buy something that looks nice but is just not good?
self_text: I want a new pair of shoes for the summer and I’ve been looking everywhere and all the ones I like are too expensive so if I see a pair that isn't super fancy or cute, but is just well-made and feels comfortable, would you consider buying them? Or should I keep looking until I find something better?

title: What is the best way to clean a stainless steel sink?
self_text: I'm trying to get rid of some water stains and hard water spots on my sink, but don't want to damage it.  I've heard people recommend vinegar, baking soda, etc.

title: Why do some people hate the word “hater” or use it as an insult?
self_text: I can see why some people would be annoyed with the word “hater”, but I don’t get what makes it so bad.   It’s just a word for someone who hates something, right?  Like “critic” or “detractor”. If you are going to call someone a hater, wouldn’t that just be like calling them an idiot or a jerk? It seems weird to me and I have no idea why.

title: Is there a way to get your dog to understand that he needs to go outside?
self_text: My dogs are very smart and have been trained, but sometimes when they want to go out they just bark at the door, and I don't know how to communicate to them that they need to do their business in an area where they can be seen by others.  I could put some small toys on the ground in front of the door, but he doesn't seem to care about them and will just continue barking until I take him outside.

title: Why do people who have to use a wheelchair always say that they are "good" at it?
self_text: I've noticed that people who use wheelchairs will often say something like, "I'm good at using my chair" or "It is easy for me." Like how would you be able to be good at doing something if it requires so much effort and thought?

title: Does the idea of the "Golden Rule" or "Treat others as you want to be treated" come from any specific religion?
self_text: I'm not sure but every time I hear about it, it's in the context of Christianity, Judaism, and Islam.  I wonder if other religions have similar ideas.

title: How does the "red eye" movie work?
self_text: I've seen a lot of reviews about how it has an effect on you where you feel like your in the film and that the scene is happening to you, and I want to know how they get the viewer to feel that way!

title: How do you make a cake that's good for people with the most severe allergies?
self_text: I’m trying to bake a cake for my friend, but he has all of the big ones, so I don’t know what ingredients not to use. It’s kind of an impossible problem and I am starting to get depressed about it.

title: How does a dog see in the dark?
self_text: I know that dogs have more rods than cones and therefore can see better in the dark, but how do they actually see?  Does it look like a black-and-white image? Is it blurry? Or are they able to see details even in the dark?

title: If you're in a relationship with someone who isn't your romantic partner, is that considered cheating?
self_text: I know it can be a complicated issue to deal with as there are many different ways people handle relationships and the concept of what constitutes cheating varies from person to person.  However, if we're talking about just physical intimacy (e.g., sex) or emotional intimacy (e.g., deep conversations), then isn't it cheating?

title: Can you use a knife to cut the skin of an apple?
self_text: I know it's not recommended, but can you do it?

title: What does the word "sarcasm" mean?
self_text: I've been trying to understand sarcasm for years but it still feels so confusing to me and I have never understood how to do it, or why people use it.  I can recognize it when I hear it but I don't know how to make it. Can anyone explain it to me in a simple way, or would it just be better if I gave up on understanding it?  Also, is it possible that sarcasm is only used by people who are incapable of expressing their true feelings?

title: Do people who have a hard time getting up in the morning take it easy or do they just force themselves to get out of bed?
self_text: I can't get out of bed for the life of me, and I don't think that I ever will be able to.  I used to be able to get up without a struggle when I was younger, but now its like if I lay down, my body refuses to move.  When I finally manage to get out of bed, I always feel exhausted until at least lunchtime.  Do people who have trouble waking up just take it easy from the start, or do they try to fight their way out of bed, which makes them more tired?

title: Why is the most popular (and only) thing to do on a rainy day is to watch TV?
self_text: I have always noticed that when it rains people tend to stay inside and watch TV, but why? It’s kind of weird because the rain has to be so annoying that you just want to hide away from it.  If you don't like watching TV then what would you do instead?  Is there anything else that is considered fun?

title: How can you make a cake and have it be both moist and fluffy?
self_text: I'm making a chocolate cake for my grandma's birthday, but the last time I made it, it was dry and crumbly.  I've tried using a lot of butter, eggs, and milk, but nothing seems to work. Also, I don't want to use any oil in it because that is why the previous cake tasted so dry.

title: What do you do with your hands when you are holding something heavy?
self_text: Like, what is the correct position for holding a box of goods that is too heavy to lift? Do you just hold it as high as possible or not? Is there a technique?

title: What's the difference between a "noodle" and a "pasta"?
self_text: I've always been confused about what exactly is different about them, and if there are any differences at all. They both seem to be used for similar things, like adding sauce to. Is there a specific type of noodle that isn't considered pasta?

title: Is it possible to be a racist without knowing what racism is?
self_text: I am not saying anyone here is racist, but there are some people who think that race is irrelevant and that all humans are equal, even if they have different customs or traditions from other cultures. What do you guys think?

title: Is it possible to get a tattoo of an animal that's extinct?
self_text: I'm thinking about getting a tattoo of a dodo bird, but I wanted to know if there was any way to do that.

title: What is the difference between a “good” and “bad” story?
self_text: In other words, what makes a good story better than a bad story? Do we have any sort of objective measurement of a good vs bad story or do they vary based on people’s subjective opinions? Are there things like plot holes, character inconsistencies that can ruin a story? Does it matter if your characters are not likable?

title: Is it possible for a baby to have a fever if he/she is just lying around?
self_text: I feel like my little boy has been in bed all day and never even got out of bed and he feels like he has a fever, but he isn't sweating or anything.  I don't want to freak out because last time he had a fever he was running around all over the place but I can't imagine him feeling this bad while laying down.

title: What is the difference between a chicken and a turkey?
self_text: Is it the same thing as saying that you eat your mother in law, but you’re just eating her flesh or something like that?

title: What's the difference between a "protest" and a "riot"?
self_text: It seems like they're often used interchangeably, but I think there are some key distinctions.

title: Is it common for a man to take his wife out on a date after getting married?
self_text: I know that some men and women take their spouse out on dates, but is it normal or just something done for tradition?

title: How does the world know of events that happen in countries with strict censorship? (ex: China)
self_text: I just read an article about a protest in Hong Kong and wondered how we can be sure what's going on over there when it's not shown to the public.  Do people who are inside China report these things, or do they get caught and punished? Is there an underground network of reporters that would share information like this?

title: How do you know if your cat is a good boy?
self_text: I've had my cat for about 2 years now and he always seems to be happy, so it's hard to tell. Like when he goes up on the counter does he give me any signs of approval? If he does, what are they?
